I happened to see a short blurb from the telegraph talking about Barak Obama's forst 100 Days. In it, he praises Churchill's decision not to torture German prisoners in WWII, citing it as an example of why the US should abandon waterboarding.
 Barack Obama's first 100 days - Telegraph
 
 Had he been a true student of history, he might have picked another hero to worship in this respect. Churchill might have stopped the torture of German POWs, but he had no problem ordering the firebombing of huge civilian populations in Germany, killing hundreds of thousanmds of civilians in the process.
 
 

 Winston Churchill wrote regarding the Dresden firebombings that killed 125k civilians:
 I ... assume that the view under consideration is something like this: no doubt in the past we were justified in attacking German cities. But to do so was always repugnant and now that the Germans are beaten anyway we can properly abstain from proceeding with these attacks. This is a doctrine to which I could never subscribe. Attacks on cities like any other act of war are intolerable unless they are strategically justified. But they are strategically justified in so far as they tend to shorten the war and preserve the lives of Allied soldiers. To my mind we have absolutely no right to give them up unless it is certain that they will not have this effect. I do not personally regard the whole of the remaining cities of Germany as worth the bones of one British Grenadier. The feeling, such as there is, over Dresden, could be easily explained by any psychiatrist. It is connected with German bands and Dresden shepherdesses. Actually Dresden was a mass of munitions works, an intact government centre, and a key transportation point to the East. It is now none of these things 

 
 This was only one of many German cities firebombed, many after Germany was in its death throes.

 Marshal of the Royal Air Force Sir Arthur 'bomber' Harris deliberately set out to destroy German cities.

 Germany was firebombing Britain.
 Britain was responding with firebombing Germany.
 As in the case of World War I, at the beginning of World War II, both Britain and Germany initially refrained from aerial attacks on civilians. However, in a repeat scenario, both sides deliberately increased their revenge bombing of civilian quarters in major cites following a series of inaccurately targeted bombing. The German forces conducted "Operation Blitz" for almost nine months from September 1940, attacking London, Coventry, Birmingham, Manchester and many other English cities, killing 60,000 civilians and destroying more than 2 million houses. On September 11, 1940, Joseph Goebbels wrote in his diary that this aerial bombing operation would be decisive in forcing the British government to surrender.JapanFocus
 
 It was a mutual interaction.

JPSartre12

OK, I apologize for exiting before finishing the thought.
 Obama used Churchill's refusal to torture German prisoners, a move that gansao rightfully identified as an attempt to prevent reciprocity by German captors of Brits. But, Churchill wasn't the pillar of morality that Obama was trying to emmulate. Churchill punished the German people, all of the German people, near the end of the war, for the "V-1 and V-2" bombings of civilian areas in England. It was truly an eye for an eye, not exactly the actions of a pillar of morality, especially when the firebombings occurred when Germany was all but finished any way.
 
 I didn't give my opinion of the firebombing, but there appears to be an assumption that I was against it but in favor of the A-bomb. Actually, I support both. Even though many of the target cities for firebombing were questionable military targets, the German population deserved no quarter from the rest of the world, IMO. They supported the holocaust and the madman responsible for it and that was enough guilt for me to be OK with the bombings.
 As for Japan, my father was part of the Pacific fleet at the end of the war. When the bombs were dropped, they were staging for a November 1945 invasion of the Japanese mainland and expecting up to 1Million Allied casualties and millions of dead Japanese civilians and military.
 It was the lesser of two evils, IMO, and took balls on Truman's part.

 Barack Obama likes Winston Churchill after all 
 By Alex Spillius World Last updated: April 30th, 2009
 
 Barack Obama has just praised Winston Churchill at his White House 100th day press conference. Not something we expected to hear, given his family's suspicion that the British hero's boys tortured his father during the Mau Mau rebellion. And given that Obama returned the Churchill bust that graced the Oval Office under Bush.
 Nonetheless, he paid respect to Churchill's decison not to torture during World War Two when German bombers were trying to beat London into submission.
 "Churchill said 'we don't torture' when the British people were being subjected to unimaginable risk and threat," he said.
 "And the reason was Churchill understood if you start taking short cuts over time that what's corrodes what's best in a people. It corrodes the character of a country."
 Waterboarding, he continued, corroded the American character.
 Barack Obama likes Winston Churchill after all – Telegraph Blogs
